reasoning: The critique targets a fairly small part of the overall case (one sub-argument under point 4 about a survey on researcher quality), so centrality is low: even if the critique fully landed, most of the position’s multi-pronged case against a strong compute bottleneck would remain. Within that narrow target, it has decent strength: the cited survey indeed doesn’t directly identify the elasticity of substitution between cognitive labor and compute (it varies researcher quality in today’s regime, not L holding K fixed across wide ranges), so it weakens the evidential support that this survey provides for “raise ρ”. However, it slightly overreaches by suggesting the survey supports complementarity; the safer claim is just non-diagnostic/consistent with both. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little to no fluff.
title: Survey evidence on researcher quality doesn't address compute complementarity
